Comments.comment:
January 31, 2024

The Honorable Gina M. Raimondo
Secretary, U.S. Department of Commerce

The Honorable Laurie E. Locascio
Director and Undersecretary of Commerce for
Standards and Technology, U.S. Department of Commerce

Re: December 8, 2023 Request for Information Regarding Draft Interagency Guidance Framework for Considering the Exercise of Bayh-Dole Act “March-In Rights” (“Guidance Framework”)

Dear Secretary Raimondo and Director Locascio:

On behalf of the ABA IP Section, I am submitting this comment to express our strong opposition to the proposed “march-in” Guidance Framework published in the Federal Register on December 8, 2023. The views expressed herein have not been reviewed or approved by the House of Delegates or the Board of Governors of the American Bar Association and, accordingly, should not be construed as representing the policy of the American Bar Association. These comments do not represent the policy or views of any government employee who is a member of the Section, its Council, or its Interest Groups.
Since 1894, the American Bar Association’s Intellectual Property Law Section (“the ABA IP Section”) has advanced the development and improvement of intellectual property laws, their fair and just administration, related policy issues, and, where necessary, litigation. As a major forum fostering a balanced view of legal issues and related policy initiatives concerning the U.S. economy, the ABA IP Section has earned trust of the Executive, Congressional, and Judicial Branches of our Government and the public as a respected and trusted nonpartisan substantive voice. Our membership includes private attorneys in law firms who represent small and large corporations; inventors; universities and research institutions; federal and state government agencies; academics; policy experts; and other attorney-“thought leaders” who are nationally recognized in this field of law.

<< please see the enclosed PDF for the rest of this comment letter >>

Fifth, no evidenced-based record has been developed to justify the issuance of the “Guidance Framework,” such as that required when an agency proposes to issue a regulation. In addition, the most relevant federal agencies, such as the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, the National Institutes of Health, the National Academy of Sciences, the National Academy of Engineering, the National Academy of Medicine, and the Department of Education, among others were not listed as participating in the “Interagency Working Group.” Further, no economic or cost-benefit analysis has been undertaken, either by the Office of Management and Budget or the independent Congressional Research Service, on the effect of the proposed “Guidance Framework” on the U.S. economy. These omissions individually and collectively evidence agency conduct that facially is “arbitrary and capricious.”

Finally, you are well aware that our country is engaged in geopolitical competition in the fields of quantum computing, artificial intelligence, semi-conductors, broad band and digital telecommunications, telehealth, and clean and renewable energy---all of which are essential for national security. The “Guidance Framework” directly undermines this essential work and is contrary to the objectives of recent joint Administration and Congressional action to authorize significant new federal grants8 and establish thirty one new Tech Hubs across the country to build on the achievements of the Bayh-Dole Act.

For all of these reasons, the Section requests the Department of Commerce abandon the “Guidance Framework” in light of this comment and those of the Association of American Universities, Association of University Technology Managers, U.S. industry groups from almost every sector in the economy, including the Chamber of Commerce, the National Association of Manufacturers, United Inventors Association, and leading intellectual property academics and redirect the resources of the National Institute of Standards and Technology to its congressionally authorized and core mission “to promote American innovation and industrial competitiveness.”

Sincerely,

Steven P. Caltrider, Chair
ABA Section of Intellectual Property Law
Comments.organization: American Bar Association Intellectual Property Law Section

attributes.title: Comments Submitted by Gregory Aharonian

Comments.comment:
I comment with regards to the issue of patent eligibility and quantum computing (Section I.3.a and II.12.a). I attach a paper, "Quantum Computing Patents/Investments Are Worthless to their Inventors/Investors". The fundamental argument is that the transaction timing/cost, and ease of workarounds, of quantum computing is such that nationally-enforceable quantum computing patents are almost impossible to enforce in the global transnational economy, where cloud servers made it impossible to enforce patents on software running on clouds (such as quantum computing algorithms). When quantum computing hardware becomes practical, it will be too easy to use patented quantum computing technologies outside the country where the patent was issued (most of which are in the US, the technology of which is easily moved to offshore servers, even for hardware). Thus, to some extent, it does not matter how patent eligible a quantum computing invention may be, if when it issues, it is unenforceable. Great inventions for end users, lousy returns for the inventors and their investors. The USPTO should inform all patent applicants, that if they are seeking patent claims based on methods running on a server, there is a high probability that their issued patent will be unenforceable (something their lawyers rarely discuss).

Specific to the issue of patent eligibility and quantum computing, is the problem of the semantics of quantum physics, and one of its applications, quantum computing. Most of the major terms of quantum physics: 'wavefunction', 'particle', 'system', 'time', 'set' and more, have no clear definition in standard physics semantics. The term 'particle' alone has 7 significant potential definitions. 'set', the most important term underlying physics and mathematics, has no definition other than the circular "A set is a collection of ..., where a collection is a group of ..., where a group is a set of ...". This doesn't matter much when doing calculations ("The Copenhagen school of 'shut up and calculate'"), but it pretty much makes claim construction impossible during patent litigation, and allows a patent examiner to correctly issue 112 rejections because of the lack of definition of terms. There are currently at least four schools of thought as to what is the semantics of quantum physics: the Copenhagens, the QBists, the Bohmians and the 't Hooftians, each with a different definition of 'measurement'. So if a quantum computing patent application uses the term 'measurement', the examiner rightly should 112-reject until a definition is provided. But which? And sadly, few patent lawyers are competent in the intricate semantics of quantum physics (the USPTO needs a separate bar exam for patent lawyers who want to practice in fields such as AI and quantum computing). Few of these patents will survive scrutiny in court during litigation, if the defendant's lawyers hire quantum physicists as experts.

An offer is made in the paper: for $20 million, an insurance policy can be created to insure the entire world against all existing and future quantum computing patents. That means that all such patents, together, are worth no more than $20 million. Since more has/will be spent on acquiring such patents, all such patents, even if all patent eligible, are worthless. Take any quantum software method patent. Move it to an offshore server. Do the calculations. Send the results back to the US. Thanks to the ClearConnect decision of the CAFC, there is no infringement.

The attached paper offers no solutions (other than instituting a global patent, and requiring patent lawyers to be technically competent in the subject matter of the patent). Rather, the paper uses quantum computing as a technology that clearly breaks the patent system at multiple points, as will future technologies, and reiterates the need for Constitutional analysis of the terms of 101/103/112.

In particular, the complex semantics of quantum computing requires, at least, that the semantics of 101/103/112 not be complex. Yet to this date, 101/103/112, the caselaw and MPEP, completely fail Due Process Public Notice requirements of the Constitution. Things are so bad that Justice Thomas was able to brag about NOT defining 'abstract' in Alice. If the patent statutes and MPEP satisfied Due Process, there would be few 101 rejections, because there would be a clear definition of 'abstract' that lawyers could use to draft non-abstract claims, in particular, non-abstract quantum computing claims. And to date, the USPTO has not written any memos on applying Due Process Public Notice to MPEP.

Impose Due Process Public Notice Requirements on statutes and MPEP, seek a global patent, and require patent lawyers to be technically competent.

Comments.comment:
July 29, 2024

The Honorable Kathi Vidal
Under Secretary and Director
U.S. Patent and Trademark Office
U.S. Department of Commerce
Alexandria, VA 22314

Re:Request for Comments Regarding the Impact of the Proliferation of Artificial Intelligence on Prior Art, the Knowledge of a Person Having Ordinary Skill in the Art, and Determinations of Patentability Made in View of the Foregoing (FRN 2024-08969)

Dear Under Secretary Vidal:

On behalf of the American Bar Association’s Section of Intellectual Property Law, I am submitting this comment to express our views in connection with the request for comments regarding the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on, inter alia, prior art as published in the Federal Register on April 30, 2024. The views expressed herein have not been reviewed or approved by the House of Delegates or the Board of Governors of the American Bar Association and, accordingly, should not be construed as representing the policy of the American Bar Association. These comments do not represent the policy or views of any government employee who is a member of the Section, its Council, or its Interest Groups. The comments also do not represent the policy or views of any individual voting member of the Section Council or his/her employer.

Since 1894, the American Bar Association’s Section of Intellectual Property Law (“the Section”) has advanced the development and improvement of intellectual property laws, their fair and just administration, and related policy issues. As a major forum fostering a balanced view of legal issues and related policy initiatives concerning the U.S. economy, the Section has earned trust of the Executive, Congressional, and Judicial Branches of our Government and the public as a respected and trusted nonpartisan substantive voice. Our membership includes private attorneys in law firms who represent small and large corporations; inventors; universities and research institutions; federal and state government agencies; academics; policy experts; and, other attorney-“thought leaders” who are nationally recognized in this field of law.

I.Introduction

The Section is proud of its long-time support for a strong U.S. intellectual property system, which in turn, provides pathways for innovation to enter the marketplace and its commercialization resulting in benefits for the public good. The Section applauds your efforts around seeking input on the impact of AI on the patent system, however, it has not adopted policy on each of the issues raised within the Request for Comments (“RFC”). This letter will provide some general comments regarding fundamental principles and answer some of the questions raised in the RFC.

Intellectual property and its legal protection are the catalysts for continued innovation. This is especially true in cutting-edge sectors like the life sciences, artificial intelligence, robotics, green tech, and quantum computing. Today, life sciences and modern medicine research and development and clinical trials have high start-up costs, require heavy fiscal investment, and can take decades to reach the market. Encouraging intellectual property protections and ensuring that innovators can protect and profit from their investments will create the proper incentive structures for continued U.S. global leadership in key industries, including the efficient and effective promulgation of lifesaving drugs. Likewise, global public health would be best served by encouraging policies that provide incentives for investment and commercialization.

The foundation of a reliable and durable national innovation system includes predictability and certainty surrounding IP rights. Any licensing or commercialization system relies on these principles of predictability and certainty around the underlying technology and legal rights for transparency and certainty in the transaction. As our Section has articulated in prior USPTO letters and its Senate testimony, the uncertainty and unpredictability about what types of inventions qualify at the most fundamental level for patenting not only undermines the U.S. patent system, but it also creates unacceptable risks to investments that American entrepreneurs choose to pursue. . . . .

<< Please see the enclosed PDF for the entirety of our comments>>

The Section thanks the Office for the opportunity to submit these comments. We would be pleased to further discuss these comments with the Office and others as appropriate. The Section encourages the Office to continue to make strides toward patent system policies enhancing efficiency, predictability, and confidence in the U.S. patent system. Should you have any questions or would like to discuss these issues further, please do not hesitate to contact me
or the Section IP Legislative Consultant Chris Katopis at chris.katopis@americanbar.org.

Sincerely,

Steven P. Caltrider, Chair
ABA Section of Intellectual Property Law
Comments.organization: American Bar Association Intellectual Property Law Section

attributes.highlightedContent: Quantum Intelligence, Inc. is a high tech startup.… We developed the Quantum Intelligence System (QIS) from a DOD SBIR contract.
attributes.title: GSAR Case 2006-G501, GSA Mentor-Protege Program (Comment #3)

Comments.comment:
Quantum Intelligence, Inc. is a high tech startup. We developed the Quantum
Intelligence System (QIS) from a DOD SBIR contract. Based on the QIS, we also
developed the Knowledge Gathering Network (KGN) product that allows
collaborative users to gather, create, and disseminate knowledge from
diversified information sources. The Knowledge Pattern Search (KPS) product
extends the KGN capability to discover knowledge patterns and apply them to
search for new, interesting, and unique information. Recently we adapted KPS as
a Collaborative Learning Agent (CLA) in the context of Maritime Domain Awareness
(MDA). Multiple CLAs can be networked to form an agent network. The networked
CLAs subsequently learn behavior patterns from the multiple data sources and can
then apply them for prediction and identification of new data. CLA has been
selected for a US Navy FORCEnet Sea Trial, the Trident Warrior 08.

We are interested in the GSA Mentor-Protege program. We have have Phase I, II
and III SBIR form DOD and DOD primes, Our technology is useful and advanced for
our warfighters for future events.

Comments.comment:
The State of Indiana is pleased to provide this response to Request for Information (RFI ) DOC-2021-0010 from the Department of Commerce (DoC), Office of Policy and Strategic Planning. Leading Indiana's vision is the George Scalise Semiconductor Innovation Center (GSSIC).

The overarching goal of Indiana’s future economic planning, research, and networking focuses on developing specific action items that the state and local governments can take to (1) equally increase resilience geographically and amongst sectors and (2) develop strategic plans that will mitigate future economic shocks, all with a careful eye toward microelectronics.

Indiana’s strategic intent is to further advance as a prominent stakeholder in the U.S. Semiconductor Industry, with a specific focus on defense needs, contributing to all sectors, including research and development, design, fabrication, and packaging and test. The goal is to support the economic imperatives of the State and the national security while building a critical mass within Indiana via stakeholders and strategic partners.

We look forward to continuing to work closely with industry, academic and government stakeholders to move forward this essential national interest item.

attributes.title: Comment on FR Doc # 211116-0234

Comments.comment:
The federal government needs to reform the rules surrounding corporate partnerships taking place in university research facilities financed with tax exempt bonds to encourage more public-private partnerships and make the U.S. more competitive with its international peers. The IRS rules on ownership of intellectual property by private sponsors of research in university facilities are unnecessarily complex and should be reformed to allow more flexibility to encourage more public/private partnerships.
mproving university/corporate research partnerships is key to advancing US competitiveness. Reform of the IRS rules surrounding corporate sponsored research taking place in university facilities funded by tax-exempt bonds has long been sought by the higher education community and will stimulate more public-private partnerships. With Congress considering new ways to fund research through a new NSF Technology Directorate and the possibility of a large infrastructure package, an opportunity is now open for Congress to address these long-standing reforms in IRS rules.

attributes.title: Comment submitted by Scio Township

Comments.comment:
National Priorities List (NPL) for Gelman Sciences Inc., Ann Arbor, MI
The following comments are submitted on behalf of Scio Township:

1) Getting trigger/cleanup levels for 1,4-dioxane below 7.2 µg/L: The current USEPA Drinking Water Concentration for 1,4-dioxane for a cancer risk level of 1 in 100,000 is 3.5 parts per billion (ppb), less than half of the 7.2 ppb adopted by Michigan’s EGLE for the same risk level. Absent an enforceable federal drinking water standard for 1,4-dioxane, many states have already adopted maximum contaminant levels or guidance standards of 1 ppb or less, conforming more closely to the EPA cancer risk level of 1 in 1,000,000 (0.35 ppb). Given the current trajectory of regulatory action on per-and poly-fluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), which are similar in many respects to 1,4-dioxane in terms of persistence and pervasiveness, we assume that USEPA Maximum Contamination Levels are likely to be established for 1,4-dioxane, as has recently been the case for many PFAS chemicals. We urge EPA to lower the monitoring well compliance trigger level and cleanup level for the Gelman site to at least 3.5 ppb, and preferably to 0.35 ppb.

2) Calling for improved plume delineation: From July 2021 to August 2022, Scio Township conducted an extensive testing program for 1,4-dioxane in residential drinking water wells. The results of the testing indicate that numerous residences located between the assumed northern boundary of the contaminant plume (as defined by Gelman) and the Huron River (located approximately one mile further north) have contaminated drinking water. In some cases, wells located more than 4,000 feet north of the assumed plume boundary have wells contaminated with more than 1 ppb of 1,4-dioxane. We urge USEPA to expand on the perimeter sentinel well network to the north and northeast to identify contaminant migration pathways that have evidently escaped detection. Additional iterative testing to the north, east, and west is necessary to fully delineate the extent of the 1,4-dioxane contaminant plume. For additional information, please review Section 1 of the Scientific/Technical Justification Expert Report submitted in May 2021 by Scio Township, the City of Ann Arbor, and Washtenaw County in state court litigation. The Gelman Intervenor Expert Report is attached.

3) Urging adoption of EPA Method 522 for all drinking water samples and require Gelman to implement a comprehensive residential sampling program: Numerous states have adopted drinking water standards that are less than 0.5 ppb. Of the currently available testing methods available for drinking water, only EPA Method 522 was specifically designed for analysis of 1,4-dioxane to a reporting level of less than 0.15 ppb. Use of EPA Method 522 was essential for Scio Township in its evaluation of 1,4-dioxane in drinking water quality conducted between July 2021 and November 2022, since several residences had concentrations below 0.30 ppb. We urge the use of USEPA Method 522 for all residential water well and public water supply analyses to provide information on exposure risks at levels consistent with the current USEPA Regional Screening Level of 0.46 ppb for potable water. Furthermore, there is no reason that local governments should bear the cost of sampling residential wells in the vicinity of the 1,4-dioxane plume. Gelman should be required to implement a comprehensive residential well sampling program which utilizes EPA Method 522.

On behalf of Scio Township,
Will HathawayKathleen Knol
SupervisorTrustee

attributes.title: Comment by American Bar Association Intellectual Property Law Section

Comments.comment:
May 14, 2024
The Honorable Kathi Vidal
Under Secretary and Director
U.S. Patent and Trademark Office
U.S. Department of Commerce
Alexandria, VA 22314
Re: Unlocking the Full Potential of Intellectual Property by Translating More Innovation to the Marketplace (FRN 2024-05504)
Dear Under Secretary Vidal:
On behalf of the American Bar Association’s Intellectual Property Law Section (“the Section”), I am submitting this comment to express our views in connection with the request for input regarding new ways to unlock the potential of intellectual property for the public good, as published in the Federal Register on March 15, 2024. The views expressed herein have not been reviewed or approved by the House of Delegates or the Board of Governors of the American Bar Association and, accordingly, should not be construed as representing the policy of the American Bar Association. These comments do not represent the policy or views of any government employee who is a member of the Section, its Council, or its Interest Groups.
Since 1894, the American Bar Association’s Intellectual Property Law Section (“the ABA IP Section”) has advanced the development and improvement of intellectual property laws, their fair and just administration, related policy issues, and, where necessary, litigation. As a major forum fostering a balanced view of legal issues and related policy initiatives concerning the U.S. economy, the ABA IP Section has earned trust of the Executive, Congressional, and Judicial Branches of our Government and the public as a respected and trusted nonpartisan substantive voice. Our membership includes private attorneys in law firms who represent small and large corporations; inventors; universities and research institutions; federal and state government agencies; academics; policy experts; and other attorney-“thought leaders” who are nationally recognized in this field of law.

(see enclosed PDF for the entirety of the comments)
In closing, the Section is very proud that the ABA has advocated for a strong IP system since the 1890s, and in turn, has been a part driving the U.S.’ innovation and commercialization phenomenal success story. The Section has previously cited a number of past USPTO studies that have shown that intellectual property intensive industries support at least 45 million U.S. jobs and contribute over 38% to the U.S. GDP. The above examples tell a compelling story of the impact of patent eligibility jurisprudence on jobs, the economy, and U.S. innovation. The stories feature precision medicine and diagnostics, but the impact crosses technology lines with patent claims directed to axles and cameras falling to the current defective section 101 legal jurisprudence. We invite your attention to these past Section letters and materials in response to the Federal Register Notice that share more of these useful case studies about innovation, entrepreneurship, and commercialization that would certainly be of value to you and your Administration colleagues in your task.12
The Section appreciates the opportunity to offer these comments in support of the USPTO’s review of new ways to unlock the potential of intellectual property and we commend the Office on its continued efforts. We would be happy to offer additional comments as the USPTO begins to assess the findings. Should you have any additional questions, we would welcome further discussion with the Office. Please contact either myself or Chris Katopis, IP Legislative Consultant, at chris.katopis@americanbar.org or 202-662-1779. Thank you.

Sincerely,
/Steven P. Caltrider/
Steven P. Caltrider, Chair

Comments.comment:
Artificial intelligence (AI) is rapidly transforming the global financial services industry. As a group of related technologies that include machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL), AI has the potential to disrupt and refine the existing financial services industry. Attached is a review the extant academic, practitioner, and policy related AI literature. The AI, ML and DL taxonomy as well as their various
applications in the financial services industry is also detailed.

A literature survey of AI and financial services cannot ignore the econometric aspects and their implications. ML methods are all about algorithms, rather than asymptotic statistical processes. Unlike maximum likelihood estimation, ML’s framework is less unified. To that end, the ML approaches of unsupervised and supervised learning is discussed. See attached report

attributes.title: Comment from Rikap, Cecilia

Comments.comment:
I hereby share a collection of my research on the Cloud, artificial intelligence (AI) and Big Tech companies that broadly addresses the RFI questions. My work (see attachments) has been published in peer-reviewed academic journals and in two books. I have also included working papers on AI and the Cloud. In the file "0. Rikap RFI on the Cloud" I summarize the content of each of each attachment and suggest a reading order that starts with the general framework and finishes with my work on the cloud and AI. The attachments can be read as stand-alone pieces or as part of my larger research program, including my most recent work on how Big Tech companies dominate the AI field and my detailed mapping of the Cloud.

Please note that I numbered the files with a suggested reading order.

Kind regards,

Dr. Cecilia Rikap
Senior Lecturer in International Political Economy
City, University of London

Comments.comment:
March 22, 2016

Docket Management System
West Building Ground Floor, Room w12-140

Reference: Amendment to PlatformBrown's Exemption No. 15091 Regulatory Docket No. FAA-2015-6041 to include additional UAS (Unmanned Aircraft Systems) on the "Approved Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) Make/Model under Section 333" (Attachment 1)
Dear Madam/Sir,
PlatformBrown, Inc. was issued Exemption No. 15091 (Docket number FAA-2015-6041) under Section 333 of the "FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012" on February 25, 2016 for the purpose of aerial data collection. PlatformBrown hereby requests an amendment to Exemption No. 15091 to allow for the use of additional UAS platforms included in the document titled "Approved Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) Make/Model under Section 333" under the same conditions and limitations contained in Exemption No. 15091. Prior exemption numbers 15453, 12862A, 15552, are similar and all feature the same approved list of aircraft. Furthermore, PlatformBrown requests that as additional aircraft are added to the "Approved Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) Make/Model under Section 333" document, those aircraft are automatically approved for use under Exemption No. 15091 by updating the PlatformBrown Operating Documents with the most current version of the document (See Attachment 1).
PlatformBrown requests permission to operate those UAS platforms approved for use under exemption No. 15091 for the purposes of aerial data collection, surveying, photogrammetry, aerial mapping, surveillance, inspection, videography, and monitoring. In prior, similar exemptions, each and every UAS platform included in Attachment 1 has been approved by the FAA for commercial operations. Each UAV to be operated will weigh less than 55 pounds. There has been no change in the conditions and reasons relative to public interest and safety that were the basis for granting the original exemptions.
PlatformBrown respectfully submits that this requested amendment would not be precedent setting. Additionally, numerous similar amendment requests have previously been approved. Therefore, PlatformBrown requests a determination that good cause exists to dispense with publication of the summary of this petition in the Federal Register and a grant of the requested amendment expeditiously by summary means.
Thank you for your timely consideration of this petition for amendment to Exemption No. 15091
Sincerely,

Jack S. Griswold Jr.
Chief Operating Officer
PlatformBrown, Inc.
6 Clock Tower Place Suite 300
Maynard, MA. 01754

attributes.title: Comment from Jeff Riolo

Comments.comment:
March 17, 2016
[Submitted electronically via internet site as instructed]

To:U.S. Department of Transportation
Docket management System
1200 New Jersey Ave., SE
Washington, DC 20590

Fr:Empower UAV/UAS, Inc.
Jeff Riolo, executive officer
1953 Magdalene Way
San Diego, CA 92110

Re:Exemption Request under Section 333 -
Second Amendment submitted for Additional UAS Air-frames & UAS Applications
FAA 333 Exemption No. 14402 and Regulatory Document No. FAA-2015-5108

Dear Sir or Madam:
Pursuant to Section 333 of the FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 1012 and 14 C.F.R. Part 11, Empower UAV/UAS, Inc, operators of Unmanned Aircraft Systems, seeks additional exemptions to include additional approved aircraft and added approved applications, none of which are precedent setting and are existing.

This requested action is for a 2nd amendment is regarding our approved FAA 333 Exemption No. 14402 and Regulatory Document No. FAA-2015-5108.

Empower UAV/UAS, inc. hereby requests FAA to consider and amend Petition's existing 333 approved exemptions to include all airworthy aircraft as denoted and periodically updated by the FAA and published on web site and update on Federal government web site www.regulations.gov and listed under Docket No. FAA-2007-3330, of which there are currently over 1100 approved UAS.

A full list of the current approved UAS aircraft as listed on the Federal government site referenced previously and provided at the end of this written request. Our current approved and 1st amendment requested aircraft are included in this list/

Additionally, we respectfully request you amend our approved FAA 333 petition to include closed-set motion picture and television filming under the standard conditions set forth in numerous other approved petitions.
As such, we respectfully request amending our Exemption No. 14402 to read as follows:

1.Operations authorized by this grant of exemption are to the petitioner to use all UAS that have previously been approved by the Secretary of Transportation under Section 333 of the FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012. UAS that have been previously approved by the Secretary, including the aircraft proposed by the petitioner, are found on the List of Approved Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) under Section 333.

The list, which is updated monthly, is posted at www.regulations.gov under docket number FAA-2007-3330. The petitioner is also authorized to operate any UAS on that list, when weighing less than 55 pounds including payload while this exemption is valid.

2.Operations for the purpose of closed-set motion picture and television filming are permitted.

Our requested application for closed-set motion picture and television filming is under the specified conditions of multiple other approved 333 petitions.
are attached as a file as documented on the current FAA list, as of March 4, 2016, under Docket and will be updated by the FAA monthly. This is a list of UAS previously approved by the Secretary of Transportation under Section 333 of the 2012 FAA Modernization and Reform Act.

The UAS attached is a word document were submitted to the FAA in petitions for exemption for UAS operations. It includes UAS readily available for purchase as well as those built by petitioners which are not available for purchase from retailers. The list is not an endorsement by the FAA of any UAS but is representative of all Federally approved UAS aircraft under Docket No. FAA-2007-3330.

If you have any questions, or need any additional information to process our amendment request to allow UAS operations with the additional requested air-frames and applications, please do not hesitate to contact the undersigned.

Respectfully,

Jeff Riolo
Executive Officer
Empower UAV/UAS, Inc.
619-990-1640 direct
jeff@EmpowerUAV.com
jeffriolo@gmail.com

attributes.title: Comment from Darrell Binnion

Comments.comment:
Dear Sir or Madam,
In the matter of amending the current exemption for Southern Survey & Design, a subsidiary of Trendsetter Construction, Inc. (Regulatory Docket No. FAA-2015-6332, Exemption No. 15302), I would like to call your attention to the following:
Conditions and Limitations
Condition No. 1:
Currently, Southern Survey & Design, a subsidiary of Trendsetter Construction Inc. is authorized by this exemption to conduct UAS operations using a DJI Phantom 3 Professional when weighing less than 55 pounds including payload.
Requested amendment:
Southern Survey & Design, a subsidiary of Trendsetter Construction Inc. requests future UAS operations to include authorization for all UAS makes/models when weighing less than 55 pounds included in the FAA document titled "List of Approved Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) under Section 333" attached to Docket ID# FAA-2007-3330, which is attached to this comment.
Whereas, all of the UAS listed under the above stated FAA document have been previously ruled as safe under past rulemaking when weighing less than 55 pounds,
Whereas, Southern Survey & Design, a subsidiary of Trendsetter Construction Inc. has operated completely within the parameters set forth in Section 333 FAA exemption No. 15302,
Whereas, approval of the amendment being offered would not affect adherence to the remaining parameters set forth in Section 333 FAA Exemption No. 15302,
Whereas, Southern Survey & Design, a subsidiary of Trendsetter Construction Inc. has observed that certain UAS operations require varied models of UAS, which, when used in accordance to the type of task, can actually increase public safety,
Whereas, Southern Survey & Design, a subsidiary of Trendsetter Construction Inc. has recognized that future determinations of approved UAS in the FAA document titled "List of Approved Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) under Section 333" will further increase the public safety in future iterations,
Therefore, Southern Survey & Design, a subsidiary of Trendsetter Construction Inc. has concluded that approving this amendment to the existing Section 333 FAA Exemption No. 15302 would be in the best interest of public safety.
All other Conditions to this Exemption are uncontested and will be adhered to.
Thank you for your time.

Comments.comment:
Re: Cloud9Drones Section 333 Exemption Amendment
Exemption No. 11778A
Regulatory Docket No. FAA-2015-0591

Dear Sir/Madam,

Cloud9Drones LLC is writing to amend our Section 333 exemption request, posted March 10th, 2015, with the intention of adding additional aircraft, or UAS, to our exemption.

The petitioner, Cloud9Drones, proposes to use UAS that have previously been approved by the Secretary of Transportation under Section 333 of the FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012. UAS that have been previously approved by the Secretary are found on the List of Approved Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) under Section 333, which is updated monthly, and posted at www.regulations.gov under docket number FAA-2007-3330. These aircraft will continue to follow the other requirements of our exemption, and will not weigh more then 55 pounds when including a payload.

Jacob Rachniowski
Managing Partner

attributes.title: Comment from Anonymous Anonymous

Comments.comment: This is not a well formed decision by the people. The people have a right to decide what laws should be taken in affect. That being said, the remote ID for unmanned aircrafts should be light information. Being tracked every second of the flight, while having all systems of the drone being monitored is a violation of the users privacy. Not only that but by enforcing the people to upgrade to remote IDs and having to pay for the system is a scam of the government. A drone or unmanned aircraft will not be safe in the air using the WiFi services. Let's take a moment and actually look farther than a couple years into the future of technology. AI will become a dominating force in the people's lives meaning access and usability to internet will be faster and more proficient. This being stated rouge unmarked hackers can now find a way into the services and override drones in the sky causing a danger or threat to the people. The only way a service using internet to have very valuable information being tracked through its whole flight would have to be a quantum computing technology. This technology will prevent any information being taken or hacked. With this being stated a basic set of information could help with future navigation to autonomous drones. Such as, importance and use of flight. Elaborating On this more meaning if it's commercial use or recreational use. From there we can set a basic set of information to the drone such as user, and builder of the unmanned craft, similar to DMV set-ups .  We can do this without fees that only serve positive for government use. Until quantum computing is a solid form of tech, then all of the tracking will only benefit those whom need to know what people are doing all day, and of those who wish to spy on private flights. Please make the more informed decision, because backlash will be a huge problem.

attributes.title: Comment from Richard Fleming

Comments.comment:
See attached file(s)

12 December 2018

To Joy at the FDA who responded to my email message left with the FDA media department yesterday, 11 December 2018,

The true tragedy here is the lack of understanding and differentiation between surrogate markers which may or may not be associated with a disease process and the actual disease process itself. As the author of the "Inflammation and Heart Disease" and "Angina" theories, my efforts to explain the interactions between certain surrogate markers and final disease has been misconstrued as briefly discussed in the first attached file. There is no relationship between changes in these markers and changes in disease, or in the initial evaluation of these diseases and surrogate blood markers. The importance is to recognize components of disease processes which may or may not be influenced to different degrees in different individuals given genetic and environmental (diet, smoking, air pollution, medications, et cetera) factors.

Such a lack of relationship would be expected in a sophisticated biological system designed for survival. The ability to actually measure this end organ disease is however now possible as I mentioned to "Joy" during our telephone conversation earlier today and as briefly discussed in the attachments. Also as discussed in these attached published papers is the importance of measuring the actual patient-specific or individual-specific disease process be that heart disease or cancer. It is now possible to measure these actual diseases themselves (both through regional blood flow differences and metabolism), unfortunately given the financial reimbursement now promised by upcoming CPT codes, there are many claiming they are now able to quantify while at the same time reporting quantified measurements, which their individual devices do not actually measure (see attachments). The misrepresentations I have brought to the attention of the FDA, which the FDA has not addressed and which I believe you will continue to fail to address, given my prior efforts to make you aware of and investigate numerous concerns including (1) coronary arteriography issues, (2) strontium-rubidium generator leaks among other problems, have only resulted in the FDA telling me there were more pressing issues which needed to be addressed.

All of this has only lead to more confusion in the field (FDA-2018-P-3102) and resulted in more harm and misrepresentation by these corporations.

That being said, I submit this rather brief discussion with documents with information relating to "biomarkers" for heart disease and breast cancer and again, make myself available to the FDA with the misguided hope that you will actually call upon me to provide testimony or assist in addressing these healthcare issues as they now relate to the prior submitted materials and the materials presented here on "biomarkers."

Respectfully,

Dr. Fleming

Genetic markers (eg. BRCA1/2)

attributes.title: Comments submitted by Mark Tornetta

Comments.comment:
The AIPLA talks about how interactive maps should be patent eligible.

From page 22:
A new “app” on a smart phone may not be patentable
because it simply incorporates obvious steps or desired
outcomes in an obvious way, using conventional tools. But
that is not a basis for Section 101 ineligibility. All apps on
all smart phones use computer implemented instructions to
transform a general purpose computer (the smart phone)
into a new machine. Using particular apps, one’s smart
phone can become, at turns: a compass, a flashlight, an
interactive map, a “yellow pages”, a pedometer, a television,
a videophone, etc. Each of these specific machines would
of course be patentable in principle if it were hard-wired
as a specific separate machine. It would be anomolous if
such marvels were rendered per se ineligible for patent
protection when combined in the smart phone with clever
software to make them interchangeable with the push of
a button. Yet that is exactly the state of affairs we face,
with the tangled jurisprudence exemplified by CLS Bank.
The tangle begs to be untied.

Comments.comment:
PART I OF LIES, GREED AND CORRUPTION

THIS DISCUSSION IS FOCUSED ON CORRECTING THE RECORD, CORRECTING SOME BASIC MISTAKES BEING MADE IN MEDICINE AND TO EXPOSE BASIC LIES BEING TOLD BY THE PHARMACEUTICAL AND NUCLEAR CAMERA COMPANIES.

These Redistribution and Quantification Lies are Designed to Pull The Wool Over Your Eyes.

Comments.comment:
Toyota Motor Engineering & Manufacturing North America, Inc. (TEMA), an U.S. affiliate of Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan, hereby submits its comments with regard to the proposed rule regarding USML Category XII (22 CFR Part 121). The proposed rule should be revised and clarifiedparticularly provisions at paragraphs (c)(2), (c)(6) and the Note to paragraph (b)(6).
The Note to paragraph (b)(6) exempts from ITAR control certain LIDAR systems for civil automotive application. Several other paragraphs of the proposed rule, however, would appear to negate the usefulness of this exemption by placing many of the critical components of LIDAR systems under ITAR control. Because an item containing an ITAR-controlled component is thereby subject to ITAR control itself, this exemption would be limited to only those systems that contain no component listed in Category XII. Because Category XII would control many components that are critical in an effective automotive LIDAR system (especially the IRFPAs discussed below), it would be difficultif not impossibleto construct a LIDAR system effective for automotive safety application that contains no ITAR-controlled component.
The Note to (b)(6) is also unnecessarily restrictive with regard to the range of the LIDAR systems for civil automotive applications. For automotive safety purposes, enhancing the range of the LIDAR means providing the driver with greater potential response time. TEMA understands that LIDAR systems for automotive application with ranges in excess of 200 meters are already under development. We suggest revising this restriction to 400 meters.
In order of preference, TEMA respectfully suggests either of the following alternatives to the Note to (b)(6):
Alternative 1: Exclude from ITAR control LIDAR components designed for civil automotive LIDAR systems:
Note to paragraph (b)(6): This paragraph Category XII does not control LIDAR Systems, components or parts of such Systems, or equipment for civil automotive applications.
Alternative 2: Exclude from ITAR control LIDAR components designed for civil automotive LIDAR systems having a range limited to 400 meters or less.
Note to paragraph (b)(6): This paragraph Category XII does not control LIDAR Systems, components or parts of such Systems, or equipment for civil automotive applications having a range limited to 200 400 m or less.
TEMA also requests revision of Paragraphs (c)(2) and (c)(6). These paragraphs would effectively preclude the incorporation of an Infrared Focal Plane Array (IRFPA) into an automotive LIDAR system. For civil collision avoidance, a LIDAR system must be able to detect and track distant objects in real time. To do so, a LIDAR needs high spatial resolution and wide coverage in a short time period (fast update rate) while the vehicle is in motion. An IRFPA is uniquely capable of achieving this performance by using time-of-flight (TOF) to instantaneously create a 3D depth map.
Together, paragraphs (c)(2) and (c)(6) would control IRFPAs with a wavelength between 900 nm and 30,000 nm. This limitation would preclude the use of IRFPAs for automotive application since, as noted below, all wavelengths potentially useful for automotive application fall within that range:
1400-1600 nmDetection of automobiles and other objects
30005000 nmPenetration of mist, dust, smoke and other small particles
1000015000 nmDetection of persons and live animals
Wavelengths below 1400 nm are not eye-safe and those above 15,000 nm are insufficiently intense for any automotive safety application.
Additionally, paragraphs (c)(2) and (c)(6) should be revised since the IRFPAs that would be controlled thereunder are already available internationally, including the following: (i) Chunghwa Leading Photonics Tech. (Taiwan) InGaAs FPA 320 x 256 (Exhibit 1); and (ii) Xenics (Belgium) InGaAs XFPA-1.7-640-LN2 (Exhibit 2).
In order of preference, TEMA respectfully suggests either of the following alternatives with regard to paragraph (c)(2):
Alternative 1: Revise Note 1 to paragraph (c)(2) to include the following:
IRFPAs used in automotive LIDAR systems are not subject to the ITAR.
Alternative 2: Revise (c)(2) to control only those IRFPAs specially designed for military application, as follows:
(c)(2) Photon detector, microbolometer detector, or multispectral detector infrared focal plane arrays (IRFPAs) specially designed for military application , , ,.
Finally, TEMA requests revision of paragraph (c)(12)(viii), which would control certain photon detector IRFPAs with a resolution exceeding 111,000 detector elements. This standard is already outdated, as the standard video graphics array (VGA) is currently 307,200 pixels. TEMA does not yet know the optimal resolution of an IRFPA in a production automotive LIDAR system, but to avoid hindering automotive safety research, we believe the restriction should be set no lower than 327,680 (640 x 512) detector elements.
Comments.organization: Toyota Motor Engineering & Manufacturing North America, Inc.

Comments.comment:
BVCA comment on provisions pertaining to U.S. Investments in Certain National Security Technologies and Products in Countries of Concern
The British Private Equity & Venture Capital Association (BVCA) is the industry body and public policy advocate for the private equity and venture capital (private capital) industry in the UK. With a membership of over 650 firms, we represent the vast majority of all UK-based private capital firms, as well as their professional advisers and investors. In 2022, £27.5bn was invested by private capital into UK businesses in sectors across the UK economy, ranging from consumer products to emerging technology. There are over 12,000 UK companies backed by private capital which currently employ over 2.2 million people in the UK. Over 55% of the businesses backed are outside of London and 90% of the businesses receiving investment are small and medium-sized businesses.
Introduction
We welcome the opportunity to comment on the Advance Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPRM) on the topics related to the implementation of the Executive Order (EO) 14105 “Addressing United States Investments in Certain National Security Technologies and Products in Countries of Concern”. We have attached our comments and look forward to further engagement.

Comments.comment: I appreciate the opportunity to respond to the Request for Information regarding the Draft Interagency Guidance Framework for Considering the Exercise of March-in Rights, dated December 8, 2023. I write this in my capacity as Senior Research Fellow at the Mercatus Center, a non-profit non-partisan research organization based at George Mason University. As I explain in the attached document, the proposed Framework would twist Bayh-Dole and weaken the U.S. intellectual property system is misguided and will harm market competition, consumer access to new technologies, and our strategic global interests in technology leadership. I strongly urge NIST to withdraw this proposed framework and uphold the Bayh-Dole Act as written. Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this critical issue.

attributes.title: Comment from Cirrus360

Comments.comment:
The US economy is driven by the rich and diverse technologies and ideas that arise from many small endeavors. From garage based startups to university research projects, the US innovation culture excels in nurturing talented people with new visions of how things should be done. Cellular technology by contrast is developed by a few powerful players (as evidenced by the distribution of 3GPP submissions and related patents) who can afford the R&D costs and the price of spectrum. Spectral policy in the US and elsewhere has already made progress on relaxing spectrum rules, allowing a more diverse set of players to participate. 6G technology must lean into this direction, not just in spectral policy, but also in equipment and system development. 6G must become a catalyst for a more diverse and creative ecosystem of developers of new solutions and must also enable and support the users of those solutions, especially in the US.

This is especially critical for small businesses, many of whom don’t have an IT department, but who need to remain competitive in the face of competition from other, perhaps larger, players. Today 5G remains too expensive and complex to install and maintain. 6G must be easy to adapt so it can be used in creative ways by a diversity of businesses for a diversity of use cases.

The Open RAN movement has made impressive progress towards providing traditional operators with stronger control over how their networks are deployed but has not yet addressed the problems outlined above regarding agility and flexibility of system development and deployment involving large and small technology contributors, and solutions customized/optimized for a diversity of use cases. Addressing these issues is key to 6G success.

6G must enable use case discovery in new markets, by the players in these markets, not cellular communications experts, so that it can spread rapidly and provide value throughout the economy. This can only happen if the value and use of 6G can be discerned by player in each potential market through dialog at a relevant depth and detail, and systems and be rapidly developed to address these markets with the required performance/price point. The ability to rapidly deploy new solutions to new markets, without the involvement of big OEMs or standardization will be essential to enable 6G success beyond the consumer market fueled by smartphones and similar consumer devices.

Our startup, Cirrus360 Corp., has developed a RAN Domain Specific Language (RDSL) driven automation framework (platform name: GABRIEL) for development, testing, deployment, and upgrades of RAN components, starting with the Distributed Unit (DU). In Mobile World Congress 2024, Barcelona, our RDSL driven Intelligent RAN Automation, was recognized with a Global Mobile (GLOMO) award in the category “Best Digital Tech Breakthrough for companies under $10 million Annual Global Revenue”. We are currently engaged with open RAN industry leaders with whom we have jointly proven the significant efficiencies to be gained from our platform. For macrocellular deployments, GABRIEL enables hardware/software system level composition, optimizing total cost of ownership (TCO). For Private 5G, GABRIEL enables use case optimized connectivity, addition of new QoS and security guarantees to 5G systems, extending open RAN and 5G standards from consumer to customized enterprise use, to making 5G work for security sensitive DoD applications and use cases.

Comments.comment:
Proposed Guidance Will Eviscerate the 40-year, $54 BB Federal SBIR Program

We are a Small Business performing R&D primarily for the Defense Department for more than 30 years. We typically earn a small profit when our R&D expenses are treated using section 162. Under prior Law and IRS policy, for every $100 of R&D contract award, for example, roughly 90% are actual R&D expenses, generating $10 of real income and cash and about $3 in Tax (at a 30% rate).

Under the proposed Guidance, our contract R&D Business Model no longer makes any financial sense. Limiting deductible expenses to only 10% of those $90 (i.e., $9) in the first year means our taxable income on the same $100 contract is now $91 (9 times higher!). At a 30% tax rate, the tax due is about $27, almost three times the $10 actual income and cash generated from the contract. We now need to use $17 of our capital to pay our taxes. For a firm primarily performing contract R&D, this is clearly unsustainable.

Much larger firms like Raytheon, Northrop Grumman and others generate profits from other sources and can pay the additional tax due under the Guidance, as has been noted in the Wall Street Journal. Smaller, less mature firms like those with SBIR/STTR awards typically don’t have the profit streams or cash reserves to pay greatly increased tax year after year.

This has multiple negative impacts for the United States:
• Many small R&D businesses will be forced into bankruptcy or will shut down. Attached please find 26 case histories of SBIR awardees describing the
devastating impact this proposed Guidance will have. Our firm, which has been very active in the SBIR program for decades, has decided it simply can no
longer participate.

• The SBIR/STTR program will effectively be crippled, as the Guidance is a strong DISincentive for small business participation. This federal program has
existed for 40 years and has funded $54 BB under almost 180,000 R&D contracts. It has been repeatedly reauthorized by Congress by overwhelming
majorities (most recently by 415-9 in 2022). This Guidance will effectively gut this program.

• The largest Government beneficiary of the SBIR/STTR program is the Defense Department, which currently funds $1.8 BB through SBIR/STTR annually,
awarding 2,400 R&D contracts to enhance US military superiority. Most of these firms will no longer Bid on DOD SBIR/STTR work under the proposed
Guidance.

• Well-capitalized small businesses (a very small minority) may continue to participate in SBIR because they can benefit from what will now essentially
become a cost-share contract. Rather than shoulder 100% of the cost of their own R&D projects, those with large cash reserves can seek Government SBIR
funding for 73% of their costs and then only bear 27% of the cost in Tax payments (using the example above).

• Now, in addition to a capital advantage, very well-capitalized small businesses will also benefit from the Preferred IP Rights in the SBIR program. This
benefit is codified in DFARS 252.227-7018 and was expressly created to “level the playing field” for SBIR awardees to encourage commercialization.
Preferred IP rights allow SBIR recipients to better compete for downstream non-SBIR Government work. Under the Guidance, most (thinly capitalized) small
businesses will be further disadvantaged vs. well-capitalized small businesses that secure SBIR awards, completely contrary to Congressional and
Government intent.

• This defeats the express Congressional intent of the SBIR program, reaffirmed every 5 years over the past 40 years. SBIR was always intended as an
INCENTIVE for Small Business to perform Government R&D for two reasons:

o Small businesses are ten times more effective converting R&D funding into new permanent jobs (the ultimate objective of the SBIR program), and
o Much of the innovation that spurs early R&D originates from small firms and startups, rather than much larger, more mature and bureaucratic companies.

• Under 162 R&D expensing, the Government benefited from a highly competitive SBIR award process, with the ratio of Proposers to Awardees about 10:1,
resulting in very high-quality R&D awards. With most small businesses unable to afford participation, and only a few well-capitalized firms bidding, this ratio
will likely drop drastically. The quality of the work performed for the Government under SBIR/STTR (at taxpayer expense) is likely to suffer from greatly
decreased competition.

Tax policy affects all elements of commerce, including performance of R&D. As commerce increasingly embraces technology, R&D breakthroughs are increasingly the basis for corporate and national competitiveness and even entirely new fields of commerce such as AI. Therefore, we urge the IRS to consider the highly negative (and unintended) effects of the proposed Guidance on other Congressional and federal objectives such as the SBIR/STTR program.

Comments.comment: I have a very important personal concern. I am severely, now almost debilitatingly, affected by wireless devices, including those found in vehicles. There are thousands of people like myself. 1. In what way will this technology be modified so that people like myself can drive and use public transportation? 2. If this technology cannot be modified, then how are people like myself supposed to function in society? We cannot live like hermitswe have to get groceries, go to the doctor, etc. Regardless of what kind of vehicle we drive, we will be affected by the radiofrequency, as it travels through the air. 3. What will you do to ensure that the health effects of this new technology be investigated prior to its widespread deployment? This means impartial investigations and studiesincluding epidemiological and cell and tissue studies. Kindly make a direct and thoughtful response to these questions, as well as the material related following these questions. Two years ago, I had no problems with cell phones or with Wi-Fi in buildings. Then, smart electric meters were installed in my city (but not on my home). Since that time I have become increasingly affected by all sorts of electrical devices, from cell phones to televisions to LED lights. Theodore Litovitz of the Catholic University patented a method to demodulate the harmful signal by adding a low frequency electromagnetic noise to the signal. This method should be further investigated and it or something like it added to the signal if it is incorporated in vehicles. Concerns About Wireless in Cars. Beginning about three weeks ago, I began to experience strange sensations going through my head, heart, and lungs when in proximity to certain vehicles. I fear I will suddenly have a loss of consciousness (however brief), that will cause me to lose control of my vehicle. About six months, ago, two young men I know, both from the same family, actually lost consciousness briefly while driving in Ann Arbor. Both are EMF sensitive. (One has had severe changes in his blood sugar levels due to a smart meter on his home [his blood sugar levels returned to normal after his mother removed the meter]. The mother is also severely EMF sensitive.) I and these two young men are not the only people to experience this, but they are two stories I will relate. Certain brands of vehicles cause me more problems than others. Even if the car drives itself, I will be unable to ride in it because of the wireless. Even if I am able to keep my own vehicle, the increased amount of wireless on the roadway will likely make driving impossible for me and many others. I cannot even fly on an airplane or take a bus or train due to the wireless. This means I cannot visit my aging parents, who live 2000 miles away from me. If you had asked me two years ago whether this technology would be a problem for me, I would have told you no. That is not the case today. Scientific DataIn Case You Have Doubts. One of the reasons that wireless technologies cause a host of seemingly odd and unrelated symptoms is that the waves knock calcium ions off the cell membrane. Calcium is plays a crucial role in neurotransmission (brain communication, heart rhythm, blood pressure, oxygen intake, etc.). See the articles in the footnote. Why some people are extremely affected by electromagnetic waves is not known, but there are literally thousands of studies showing that cells are affected by themusually in a deleterious way. Only a few epidemiological studies have been conducted. All of them indicate that peopleeven those who feel no changes in their healthare adversely, often severely, affected. There is mounting evidence that most people will be affected over the long term. If you studied a group of smokers for a day or three months, or even a year, you would likely find no changes in their health status. This is not an indication that tobacco is not harmful, as we now know, 40 years later. So it is with the wireless frequencies so commonly used today. Why You, As a Public Official, Should Be Concerned. As you can see from my story, someone can start off with few or no problems with electromagnetic frequencies. Saturation of our environment leads to increased sensitivity. One cigarette twenty feet away from you might not be a problem. Unlike with cigarettes, most people arent even aware of the presence of these electromagnetic frequencies (they cant smell or see them), so do not know they are being affected or do not know why they are suddenly having health problems. Electromagnetic frequencies cause breaks in the structure of DNA. Over time, this leads to cancer. It will take one two decades to see the effects of the pervasive, 24/7 use of these technologies. Childrens brains are the most sensitive, and it is in our children and grandchildren that we will see the worst of the adverse affects of these seemingly time-saving technologies. Sincerely, Linda Kurtz

attributes.title: Comment from China Chamber of International Commerce

Comments.comment:
The China Chamber of International Commerce(CCOIC), on behalf of the Chinese business community submits the comments on Advancing Inclusive, Worker-centered Trade Policy in the U.S. This commentary mainly elaborates on the damage of the U.S. policies towards China to its own economic development interests, focusing specifically on four aspects of section 301 tariffs, investment restrictions, export control and economic sanctions, and the Uyghur Forced Labor Prevention Act, which can be divided into the following four points.

I.Section 301 Tariffs imposed on China have contributed to high inflation in the U.S., increased in unemployment rate in the U.S., jeopardized the survival of small enterprises, impaired the resilience and stability of the supply chain, undermined the economic well-being of consumers, and fueled inflation.

II.Investment restrictions against China have reduced the international competitiveness of American companies and increased the transaction costs of American companies and the uncertainty of the industrial chain.

III.Export controls and economic sanctions against China have reduced revenues of American companies, curbed new investment and undermined the cooperative arrangement of American companies.

IV.The Uyghur Forced Labor Prevention Act has blocked global imports into the United States, increasing the burden of proof on U.S. importers and suppliers, raised the price of relevant U.S. imports, and harmed the rights and interests of minority groups both domestically and in the Xinjiang region.

CCOIC calls on the U.S. Government to face up to the important role of China as a trading partner in promoting U.S. economic development, realize that open and free market access and an equal and healthy competition environment are the cornerstones of economic development, and suggest that the U.S. comprehensively examine the adverse impact of its trade policy towards China on its domestic economic development and employment in an objective and open position, and promptly eliminate such trade restrictions.

For the full text of the comments, please see attached.

Comments.comment: The University of Notre Dame has a long history of cooperation and collaboration with the Federal Government dating back to World War II and continuing to the present (https://nrotc.nd.edu/general-information/). Notre Dame has close ties to the semiconductor industry, from the early days of the Semiconductor Research Corporation (SRC, 1983, https://www.src.org/about/corporate-annual/) to its recent leadership roles in running national semiconductor microelectronics centers sponsored by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) and the SRC (see response to question 6). Notre Dame collaborates closely with the State of Indiana and regional universities including Purdue and Indiana University to contribute to U.S. leadership in semiconductor manufacturing and workforce development. This response is submitted on behalf of Notre Dame faculty to answer selected questions and express Notre Dame interest to support workforce development, research, and innovation, toward U.S. leadership in semiconductor manufacturing and microelectronics.

Comments.comment:
Dear Messrs. Orji and Ramaswamy,

MITRE Engenuity is submitting this response in support of the above referenced Request for Information from the Department of Commerce and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), regarding “Incentives, Infrastructure, and Research and Development Needs to Support a Strong Domestic Semiconductor Industry.”

Our vision for the NSTC and NAPMP is to create a new paradigm for innovation that will impact U.S. technological leadership for decades to come. The creation of the NSTC and NAPMP is a once-in-a-generation opportunity to secure U.S. leadership in semiconductors. The NSTC and NAPMP will have to be structured to accommodate the complex priorities and collective vision of the U.S. semiconductor ecosystem. Closing the gap between R&D and commercialization will accelerate innovation and enhance supply chain resilience for economic and national security.

MITRE Engenuity has a heritage of neutrality, commitment to the public good, strategic vision, and commitment to the mission of solving problems for a safer world. MITRE Engenuity has founded The Semiconductor Alliance, a collaborative effort with leading organizations from the U.S. semiconductor ecosystem and academia to begin to design the framework for the NSTC and NAPMP. For the NSTC and NAPMP to be successful, they must unite world-leading research and development in our universities, national laboratories, our industry-leading corporations, and the ingenuity of our entrepreneurs.

If you have any questions regarding our submission, please contact Dr. Raj Jammy, CTO (rjammy@mitre-engenuity.org). MITRE Engenuity looks forward to further opportunities to assist the government in achieving its goals.

Warm regards,
Dr. Laurie Giandomenico, CEO
Email: lg@mitre-engenuity.org

Encl.
•SEMI Survey Highlights Member Recommendations for U.S. Chip Industry Competitiveness, Government Investment (pdf document).
•American Innovation, American Growth: A Vision For The National Semiconductor Technology Center (pdf document).

attributes.title: Comment from David Morrison, radiation nation

Comments.comment:
Apply NEPA to wireless technology, specifically microwave radiation from cell towers and more specifically the impending 5G roll out. Confirmed by FCC there is no proof that it is safe !!!
How can this be that our regulatory agencies are captured by the telecommunications industry, are not working on behalf of public safety but rather on behalf of corporate profits. Society cannot survive wilth this paradigm any longer. All environmental infrastructures are collapsing. We are in the midst of an insect apocalypse, massive bird extinctions, bat populations an near extinction levels and half the population has some kind of chronic disease. Meanwhile we need a death penalty for corporate hacks like Adjit Pai and other industry assassins that continue to market wireless technology when they know how dangerous it is. Science continues to be either ignored or suppressed as our government agencies continue their complicity in killing people, insects and animals. Even tree die offs from placement of cell towers has been confirmed. The Dept. of the interior wrote a letter ( http://1.usa.gov/1jn3CZg ) to the FCC complaining of the effects of cell towers on bird populations. Corrpution between government and industry is completely transparent, no longer even hidden behind a veil of half truths. Everybody knows that our regulatory agencies are corrupt and on the take.
Apply NEPA to the 5G roll out. The climate debacle cannot take the amount of energy necessary to power a cell antenna every 100 feet.
David Morrison /

attributes.title: Comment on FR Doc # 2022-01305

Comments.comment: The University of Notre Dame has a long history of cooperation and collaboration with the Federal Government dating back to World War II and continuing to the present (https://nrotc.nd.edu/general-information/). Notre Dame has close ties to the semiconductor industry, from the early days of the Semiconductor Research Corporation (SRC, 1983, https://www.src.org/about/corporate-annual/) to its recent leadership roles in running national semiconductor microelectronics centers sponsored by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) and the SRC (see response to question 6). Notre Dame collaborates closely with the State of Indiana and regional universities including Purdue and Indiana University to contribute to U.S. leadership in semiconductor manufacturing and workforce development. This response is submitted on behalf of Notre Dame faculty to answer selected questions and express Notre Dame interest to support workforce development, research, and innovation, toward U.S. leadership in semiconductor manufacturing and microelectronics.

attributes.title: Comment from Richard M Fleming, MD, JD

Comments.comment:
Attn: Divisions of Dockets Management.

The FDA has failed in it's responsibility to protect USA citizens. This comment includes FOUR very specific items of concern.

FIRST, by failing to require the pharmaceutical companies which have produced Sestamibi and Tetrofosmin to note that their radioactive isotopes "redistribute" and only require a single dose of isotope instead of two, the FDA has failed in its responsibility to protect the public from unnecessary exposure to radiation and it has allowed these companies to bill for multiple doses of isotope instead of a single dose. This has increased the costs of studies both for patients and insurance companies including CMS payments. These pharmaceutical companies are aware of this redistribution property and have been aware of it for almost two decades. This reporter has published multiple papers in peer reviewed medical journals, presented at multiple medical conferences and has in fact corresponded with these companies who admit to the redistribution. The FDA has allowed this practice through it's review of the companies literature and has failed to correct this despite being notified of this previously.

SECOND, the Federal Government, through CMS has established CPT billing codes for payment of "quantification" of nuclear imaging, most specifically PET imaging. PET imaging methods reported as "quantitative" are NOT quantitative. As established in the medical literature, there is only one actual method for quantification and the FDA has not acted upon the claims made by the nuclear camera companies that their systems quantify. In fact, the companies are misrepresenting what they call "quantification" and this too has been established in the peer reviewed medical literature by the reporter.

THIRD, Nuclear TRUE quantification requires the calibration of nuclear cameras to a known standard. This is true for every other field of science. This is a requirement to guarantee that all tools used to measure scintillations are actually able to measure scintillations. There has been only one patented method for this calibration of nuclear cameras. This patented method (FMTVDM) provides for "Quantitative Control" in contrast to "Qualitative Control" and it is this "Quantitative Control" which is required to guarantee that nuclear cameras are actually measuring what they are reporting they are measuring. The reporter has published in the peer reviewed medical literature and presented at medical conferences proof that specific settings currently used in nuclear cameras (both SPECT and PET) result in a 33.95 error rate, making any further efforts to "quantify" outcomes completely meaningless and misrepresentative of the science.

FOURTH, Approval of "micro-dose" mammography under the pretense that it exposes the woman or man to less radiation than a conventional mammogram. While dense breasts exist in half of the population, requiring state legislation to address the failure of the FDA to issue warnings about the limitations of mammography, even after the NCI and Canadian Trial have demonstrated there is no "survival benefit" associated with mammography, the FDA has failed to address this failure of mammography. Adding to the problem is the approval for micro-dose (3D-tomosynthesis) with the claim that it reduces a woman or mans radiation exposure. In truth, if the FDA were to read the patent, the amount of radiation "per slice" is less, but the same is true for any test if one only looks at part of something-it is less than the whole. The actual radiation delivered is greater using this "micro-dose" approach without any demonstrable benefit to the U.S. population. In fact, there are typically between 7-11 slices per breast image and when added together, which is what one needs to do to determine the total impact, the actual dose is greater. A fact which should be obvious considering that conventional mammography uses 24-32 kVp while tomosynthesis uses 25-50 kVp.

The FDA has failed to protect the public by (1) not correcting the misinformation about isotope redistribution and the need for only a single dose of isotope, increasing costs, inaccuracy and patient radiation (2) not requiring nuclear camera companies to only claim "quantification" when they are truly "quantifying" which requires "quantitative calibration", (3) not requiring nuclear cameras undergo "nuclear quantification calibration" using the patented method approved by the USPTO and (4) allowing the use of "micro-dose" 3D-tomosynthesis which increases radiation exposure without benefit, while being allowed to claim it reduces radiation exposure.

More material is available upon request.

I encourage the pharmaceutical, mammography and nuclear camera companies to be transparent, honest and to demonstrate the integrity commensurate with their responsibilities to the people they are selling their tests and radioactive isotopes to.

Respectfully,

Dr. Fleming

Hello USCIS/DHS,

I am attaching a PDF I found from the internet to justify visa fraud especially because H1bs is for specialized jobs. But now that the employee-employer relation has come into picture, these companies are not able to find people to join them. So,if this rule is implemented, most H4 EADs will join such companies and we will see more advertisements like this.

"Wanted H4 EAD candidates for C# or .NET programming. Free training after a long break in your career, free guest house to live till you get the project, guaranteed placement(because someone in the ad-posting company itself will answer interview call)"

This is going to be the future of these H4 EAD approval. Please do not pass this rule as it will negate the value of legal immigrants like us who have done masters and got H1bs with established consulting companies like Deloitte, Infosys, TCS, Wipro or even consulting companies established in the 90s that have been following employer-employee relation.

Please check the PDF for more details.

Thanks!

attributes.title: Scott Loftin - Comments

Comments.comment:
One thing is clear; politicians don’t like little airplanes. In fact, contrary to what they state, they don’t like freedom in general and flying is one of the most prominent symbols of freedom we have. They are taking our freedoms away slowly and surely; just like boiling a frog. And 9/11 was an excellent opportunity for them to take a quantum leap in this direction. I sit here in Los Angeles writing this as TFRs are to take effect in an hour or so. I am a consultant who flies into Van Nuys nearly every day from way out in the desert to work on high tech stuff including a cure for the blind. I realize that some precautions need to be taken when the president travels, but 30 nautical miles? What has Mr. Bush got to do that is more important than what I and everyone else around here who flies has to do? Mr. Bush, I voted for you, but if you are afraid of little airplanes please stay home and video-conference. I really feel sorry for those who live around Washington who will have to put up with this permanently. This is not in the American spirit. Another person who wrote in likened the D.C. ADIZ to a wall in the sky. Mr. Bush, tear DOWN this wall!

Scott M. Loftin
Rosamond, CA
