Comments.comment:
Please see attached response from SIONYX, LLC, to question #26: What other information should inform the CPO's implementation of the CHIPS incentive programs?

CMOS image sensor semiconductor chips play an essential role in our national economy and security, yet there is no state-of-the-art domestic fab capability for R&D or manufacturing of these chips. All of this activity currently occurs in overseas fabs, primarily in Asia. The attached white paper gives a summary of why this industry is so essential to our nation, and why CHIPS Act funding support should be considered to ensure domestic capability in the future.

Please see "Growing Economic and National Security Risk Caused by Dependence on Foreign R and D and Manufacturing for Electronic Image Sensor Semiconductors.pdf" for our comment.

The other pdf files are references embedded in the white paper response.

Best regards,
Chris Vineis
VP of Engineering
SIONYX, LLC
cjvineis@sionyx.com
(978) 922-0684 x141

Comments.comment:
I found it extremely odd for this regulation to be put in. This is an act to kill and restrict H1-B visa programs for high skilled foreign workers. It is going to harm the United States and its people in various ways and here are a few reasons for my argument:

1. This sends a clear message that the United States does not welcome foreign workers, which discourage talents around the world to congregate in the Land of the Free. The reason that the United States has been No.1 in the world in technological advancement and leader in science and economy is thanks to countless skilled and talented foreign workers who came to the US and built their lives here. Many examples including scientists who were involved in the Manhattan Project. Albert Einstein, Sergey Brin, Elon Musk, leoh Ming Pei, etc. were famous foreign talents that made this country great. I once heard as long as the US is still attracting all the talents around the world, it will keep standing on the mountain top. Sadly, this is no longer true with the current administration who blame US job loss to foreign workers who actually fill jobs that couldn't be filled by Americans. If this goes for long, the US will lose the race of collecting talents to other Western countries like Canada, UK, Australia, and developing economy like India and China.

2. Making the prevailing wages high certainly can discourage Tech giants and multiple industry from hiring foreign workers. The problem is whether the US labor market can supply those industries with skilled domestic employees. Based on the current statistics, international students made up a large portions of college, master, and PhD students in the field of STEM. They were admitted to the program not only because the schools and programs wanted their money, but also because the programs deem them qualified to be studying in those fields. The majority of these students plan or planned to start a career in the US. We are talking about students who will be experts in Machine learning, Artificial Intelligence, Biomedical Engineering, Quantum physics, Advanced Chemical synthesis, and even complex trade model design. Making those students' life hard is first harmful for US economy, and second making it easier for them to bring their talent elsewhere.

3. Foreign employees work harder and have high loyalty to their employers due to Visa sponsorship. US citizens and permanent residents have wider options due to the lack of risk of deportation. So they explore their options more and collect more wages and have higher tendency to be uncooperative towards companies' decisions. Foreign employees receive lower wages and work their butt off to create more values for the company. This exploitation has been crucial for tech companies' success. Tech industry is the future and will be the backbone of this nation as the history progress. Harming their interests might seem fun and empowering now, but as the time goes on, the US will lose the race to tech giants from other countries. Even worse, US tech companies may start moving elsewhere that has more flexible work and immigration policy for their work force to be at the best shape.

I whole hearted oppose this regulation and I think it will do more harm than good for the US economy and global dominance.

attributes.title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Business Forward (web)

Comments.comment:
We write today to express our support for the Clean Power Plan and encourage the Environmental Protection Agency to keep the rule in place. The CPP provides the certainty businesses need to continue investing in clean energy, and it is essential to United States' commitment under the Paris Agreement on Climate Change. Most importantly, as China continues to invest in non-carbon energy sources, American must not fall behind.

Any discussion about regulation should consider the economic impact that it will have on companies of all sizes. This means measuring the cost of the regulation itself but also the costs of the problem the regulation is intended to fix. As we consider the future of the Clean Power Plan, it is important to understand that the minimal potential increase in electricity rates pales in comparison to the costs we experience because of severe weather and climate change.

We represent a wide range of business sizes, types, and sectors, but we are all increasingly vulnerable to climate change. The restaurant owners among us face increasing food prices. The manufacturers among us experience more downtime because parts or materials don't make it to the factory in time. IT companies worry about power loss, and real estate developers and insurance companies caution that more frequent natural disasters make property far more vulnerable. Retailers warn about severe weather's impact on foot traffic.

Almost every business has lost time and money because of travel delays.

As fellow business leaders, we encourage the Trump Administration to maintain the CPP. It will help ensure the United States plays a leading role in developing the new energy technology that will power the world and will help curb climate change by reducing our carbon output.

See attached file for signatories

attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Surya Ganguli

Comments.comment: I am a professor at Stanford who has trained many foreign PhD's who have gone on to contribute to the American economy at major tech companies.  This proposed policy is extremely misguided. Many technical PhD's in the US can take 6 years or more.  My own PhD in theoretical physics took me 6 years. Some extremely difficult PhD's can take 8.  For example, a recent PhD from Berkeley made a major advance in quantum computing, which is a major national initiative, by concentrating on a single problem for 8 years.  It is difficult to know ahead of time how long any given PhD will take. Part of the reason America has been successful is that we have been able to attract the best and brightest to our shores to complete PhD's and we have been able to retain them to work in the US.  This ability has given us an immense technology advance and boosted our GDP significantly according to many well known economic analyses.  As a professor at Stanford, who trains many PhD students, I can attest to the fact that we simply will not be able to attract foreign nationals if we put a hard limit on their stay.  We will cede our incredible talent advantage to other nations, rendering the US extremely uncompetitive economically and technologically.  Please stop this insane attempt to undercut American competitiveness, in the face of what appears on the surface to be blatant xenophobia.

attributes.title: Comments Submitted by American Bar Association Intellectual Property Law Section

Comments.comment:
Re: USPTO Patent Eligibility Jurisprudence Study (PTO-P-2021-0032-0002)

Dear Acting Director Hirshfeld:

The American Bar Association Section of Intellectual Property Law (“Section”) thanks the United States Patent and Trademark Office (“USPTO”) for the opportunity to provide comments in response to the USPTO patent eligibility jurisprudence study set forth in the Federal Register Notice on July 9, 2021 (“Notice”). The views expressed herein are presented on behalf of the Section of Intellectual Property Law. They have not been reviewed or approved by the House of Delegates or the Board of Governors of the American Bar Association and, accordingly, should not be construed as representing the position of the Association.

Since 1894, the Section has advanced the development and improvement of intellectual property laws and their fair and just administration. As the forum for rich perspectives and balanced insight on the full spectrum of intellectual property law, the Section serves within the ABA as a highly respected voice in the intellectual property profession, before policy makers, and with the public. Section members include attorneys who represent patent owners and applicants, accused infringers, small to large corporations, universities, and research institutions across a wide range of industries. Our members are attorneys in private practice, in-house counsel, public sector attorneys, and others.

I.Observations and Experiences

We commend the USPTO for its initiative in undertaking the further study of these issues of fundamental importance not only to the patent bar but for the public in general. The interpretation of section 101 of the patent statute (35 U.S.C. § 101) defines the types of inventions and discoveries that are eligible for patent protection and thereby the contours of our innovation ecosystem.

The Section appreciates the USPTO’s continued efforts to implement examination guidance in light of the challenges posed by the current state of U.S. legal jurisprudence. We also commend the efforts of the USPTO over the past decade to improve patent quality, especially in technologies that have been the subject of patent eligibility questions in the USPTO as well as in the courts. We encourage the USPTO to continue those efforts in order to strengthen the validity of issued patents and reduce the uncertainty and unpredictability with respect to patent eligibility requirements. Today, patent subject matter eligibility is ever more uncertain, ambiguous, and unpredictable, as evidenced by recent federal court opinions that have effectively left the system “broken” in the eyes of many.

The Section has provided comments to governmental inquiries following the decisions of the Supreme Court in Bilski, Mayo, Myriad, and Alice, as well as subsequent applications of that precedent by the Federal Circuit. Of note is that we believe the summary of the status of the case law in the Supplementary Information of the Notice is a fair statement of the current law including the recent expansion of patent eligibility jurisprudence by the Federal Circuit into a broad range of technologies (e.g., mechanical drive shafts).

Our Section has voiced particular concern about the effect the current status of eligibility law has had and will likely continue to have in at least three primary areas:
•Negative effects on small businesses, midsize ones, and individual innovators, to whom patent protection of new technology is critical to their success and ability to secure investment;
•Loss of global competitiveness as certain technologies are recognized as patent eligible in major competitor countries like China, but not in the U.S., which over time risks moving R&D overseas where these technologies may be more easily protected than in the U.S.; and,
•Diminishment of licensing activity and loss of a U.S.-centric international licensing regime particularly with respect to SEPs and other technologies tied to large international portfolios.

The entirety of our comments are enclosed in the corresponding PDF.

As USPTO studies have shown, intellectual property intensive industries support at least 45 million U.S. jobs and contribute over 38% to the U.S. GDP. The above examples tell a compelling story of the impact of patent eligibility jurisprudence on jobs, the economy, and U.S. innovation. The stories feature precision medicine and diagnostics, but the impact crosses technology lines with patent claims directed to axles and cameras falling to section 101. Appendix A maps these stories to the specific questions in the Notice. If further opportunities arise in connection with the Notice or subsequent notices, the Section would be pleased to supplement its response. Should you have any questions or would like to discuss these issues further, please do not hesitate to contact me.

Sincerely,

Kim R. Jessum, Chair
ABA Section of Intellectual Property Law
Comments.organization: American Bar Association Intellectual Property Law Section

attributes.title: MS: MarineMaterials -  Brawley, Susan

Comments.comment:
October 1, 2019

NOSB Materials Subcommittee-Marine Algae

To Whom It May Concern:

I am a Professor of Marine Science and Botany at the University of Maine, and I have published extensively on the basic biology of mid-intertidal macroalgae for over 35 years. ,

1.How can the NOP define, measure, and verify the phrases not destructive to the environment and sustain the growth and production as related to wild harvested marine macroalgae?
I think the main principle is that the relative abundance at a larger scale of the harvested alga should not be changed much by harvesting over time, hence ecosystem and associated species are maintained---and that harvesting will not remove the target species in a way that would make it easier for non-native species to become established. In my scientific opinion, this really has to be stated specifically on a species level. For example, the harvested alga Ascophyllum nodosum survived the last glacial maximum in North America (Olsen, J. L. & Stam, W. T. 2000. Separating population structure from population history in Ascophyllum nodosum (Fucales). J. Phycol. 36S:523). and is very abundant across the North Atlantic. It has been harvested sustainably in many areas of the North Atlantic for centuries, and how to manage for sustainable harvest is known (see DMR Fisheries Management Plan for Ascophyllum, attached). In contrast, climate change is causing overheating events in coastal waters that are having a negative impact on many kelp species in many parts of the world (but not everywhere); thus, harvest management to be sustainable must take into account whether kelp resilience is changing. In Morocco, wild harvest of the small red alga Gelidium (an agar producer) was too intensive in recent years, and the government has restricted harvest, according to what Ive read in Nature press reports.

2. Could practice standards or guidelines be created ....
Unlikely. Reproduction, life spans etc. are too different across the macrophytic marine algae that are harvested. For example some kelps are annuals while others are perennial. Some algae that are harvested lose biomass annually due to natural causes (e.g., breakage of Ascophyllum nodosum in storms and from ice shear in estuaries in winter, for example, Vadas, R. L., W. A. Wright, and B. F. Beal. 2004. Biomass and productivity of intertidal rockweeds in Cobscook Bay. Northeastern Naturalist 11(special issue 2):123-142), but regenerate (FMP, 2014) from short shoots or holdfasts (see FMP, 2014).

3. What are the environmental implications of taking no action? It could be serious or inconsequential. See my answer to Q1.
4. Define an efficient, science-based method for measuring existing biomass to establish a baseline. How would this be measured post-harvest? Is there existing data from established harvest regions?
There are transect/random sampling designs for doing so (e.g., the FMP), but I expect drones and GIS maps will increasingly be used, especially for intertidal species.
5. For all algae, what are the best methods for harvesting that minimize the impact on the recovery of the population of the harvested species and maintain ecosystem function and services? What would be measured and what benchmarks would be set? Who should determine the methods/benchmarks?
I again think this is a species-specific matter, and one a state or national governmental regulatory body is best able to make.
6.Are there some species that are so important to ecosystem structure and function that harvest should not be permitted at all?
Not, I think, in the case of marine algaebut management will be very different among species, and harvesting should be managed to avoid loss of ecosystem structure and function.
7. Should there be protected areas that are off limits to harvesting? Should seasonal restrictions be considered?
Definitely, yes. Marine Protected Areas are important as baselines to measure natural change that might otherwise be thought to be due to harvesting practices, and for sustainable ecosystem function, including as a source of propagules to maintain genetic diversity and recruitment of species being fished/harvested adjacent to the no-harvest areas.
8. What is an acceptable level of bycatch? Should this be assessed on a species by species basis? Are there any bycatch species that could prevent harvesting in an area altogether?
I think this must be assessed on a species basis and with sensitivity to harvest mode and season. In a demonstration that members of the Maine DMR Ascophyllum Fisheries Management Plan members saw with a mechanical harvester in 2013 (2014?), large packs of Ascophyllum were cut and bundled by a mechanical harvester on the Maine coast. In taking apart one of these large bales, bycatch was 2 small periwinkle snails (insignificant bycatch in that demo).


Susan H. Brawley, Ph.D
Professor

Comments.comment:
To Whom It May Concern:

Arch Aerial LLC (AALLC) requests to amend Arch Aerial's existing Section 333 Exemption No. 11283, which can be found in Docket FAA-2014-0857, to include exemption from Federal Aviation Regulations ("FARs") detailed below for authorization to operate all UAS previously approved pursuant to the Section 333 exemption process (listed in the documented attached and entitled "Approved Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) Make/ Model under Section 333"), in addition to the current standing exemption for the AALLC OCTO.

Attached to this comment is a packet containing the following documents:

Section 333 No. 11283 AALLC Amendment Request
Exemption Requests
Arch Aerial LLC Section 333 Exemption No. 11283
Arch Aerial LLC COA FAA-2014-0857
FAA List of Previously Approved Aircraft

Attached as separate PDF's are the following:

Monthly Maintenance Inspection Checklist
Go-For-Flight Pre-Flight Checklist

AALLC is submitting this petition on its own behalf. If the FAA requires any modifications to our amendment request to add approval for the aircraft previously approved by the Secretary of the Department of Transportation for operation under previous Section 333 exemptions, Arch Aerial requests the opportunity to amend this petition to include any modifications the FAA may require before granting or rejecting the petition for amendment. Arch Aerial will amend its petition to meet any additional standards for the integration of UAS operation into the NAS.

AALLC also requests that this petition for amendment not nullify its current permitted operations using the AALLC OCTO.

AALLC has also recently submitted a petition for amendment to Section 333 Exemption No. 11283 (Document ID: FAA-2014-0857-0028) to include permission to operate the Volantex Ranger in the NAS. AALLC requests that this petition for amendment not nullify approval for AALLC commercial operation of the Volantex Ranger in the NAS.

AALLC has also recently submitted a petition for amendment to Section 333 Exemption No. 11283 to include permission to operate the DJI Inspire 1 in the NAS. AALLC requests that this petition for amendment not nullify approval for AALLC commercial operation of the DJI Inspire 1 in the NAS.

AALLC has also recently submitted a petition for amendment to Section 333 Exemption No. 11283 to include permission to operate the FPV Model 2.6M Mugin in the NAS. AALLC requests that this petition for amendment not nullify approval for AALLC commercial operation of the FPV Model 2.6M Mugin in the NAS.

AALLC also requests that the FAA keep materials labeled "CONFIDENTIAL" from the public record for the purpose of maintaining our intellectual property.

We thank you for your time and look forward to your response. A grant of authorization for this amendment will allow Arch Aerial LLC to continue to serve the public interest through the provision of new and innovative services to its customers, while simultaneously maintaining its position as a leader in the safe and responsible integration of UAS in the NAS.

Best Regards,
Ryan Lee Baker
CEO, Arch Aerial LLC

attributes.title: Comment from AFL-CIO

Comments.comment:
Unions have serious concerns with both the premise and the impact of Schedule A designations. Nationwide labor shortages are a misleading and artificial construct, and unions assert that they cannot and should not be determined in a blanket fashion. Moreover, when the response to perceived shortages is to permit employers to hire from abroad without even looking for workers domestically, those labor market distortions risk turning temporary shortages into structural shortages.

The attached comments begin by explaining how predetermined labor shortage designations harm workers, using the impact of Schedule A on the nursing workforce as illustration. To prevent adverse effects on wages and working conditions, we urge DOL to restrict Schedule A to only those positions that require exceptional ability in the sciences, arts, or performing arts (currently Group II). Should the Department decide to proceed with broader Schedule A designations, robust, transparent occupational assessments must be undertaken at regular intervals. We outline indicators that should be considered in determining which occupations to include, and urge particular caution to prevent interference in labor standard setting for emerging industries.

Prolonged Schedule A designation for nursing has failed to improve systemic staffing challenges in the healthcare industry, we therefore recommend that RNs be removed from Schedule A. We further believe that the designation of any STEM or STW occupations on Schedule A is inappropriate and unjustifiable based on currently-available economic data. Simply put, there is no broad-based shortage of STEM workers that could justify Schedule A designation. Many qualified U.S. graduates with STEM degrees are working outside the field or unable to find STEM-related employment. Wages in STEM occupations have not increased in real terms, working conditions are frequently harsh, and employer attitudes towards worker organizing hostile: all phenomena that are inconsistent with the purported shortage asserted by employers. The volatility in this occupational sector and its tendency to go through boom-and-bust cycles that involve extensive layoffs further underscores the need for context-specific labor market testing, rather than a broad exemption from such testing.

Finally, we present preferred alternatives to Schedule A, and call for substantially elevated protections for workers in any occupation with a Schedule A designation.

attributes.title: Comment from Future Union

Comments.comment:
Future Union is grateful for the opportunity to submit comments to the U.S. Department of the Treasury’s proposed rule on outbound investment. This rule follows Executive Order 14105, which declared a national emergency on the investment in national security products that benefited our adversaries. For too long we have had an open door policy to investing in countries of concern and helping them develop the tools that undermine our national security. This proposed rule must protect our national security to the fullest extent possible.

The era of globalization and the admission of China to the World Trade Organization (WTO) saw the global economy become more interconnected with capital flows between countries skyrocketing. An international environment focused on deepening trade ties with lower tariffs and a global investment environment saw fund managers and capital market actors in the United States chase gains in countries of concern. At the time, China was seen as the adversarial threat it is recognized as today by only a handful of forward-thinking national security officials. Today that recognition is near universal but the actions we take today should have been taken years ago. We are playing catch-up to a country that has been planning our downfall for years.

One of the most compelling reasons to stop outbound investment to China is to protect vital national security interests including the development of cutting edge technologies. Investments in key sectors such as technology, healthcare, defense, and energy all have material impacts on our national security if our adversaries gain a headstart. Financing your enemy is akin to cutting off your nose to spite your face. The difference being, some are actively profiting on undermining America’s security. The government can and should act to stop this.

The Chinese Communist Party’s ever present involvement in the activities of so-called private entities in China means that there is no separation between business and state. They are two heads of the same beast and we cannot continue to pretend otherwise. Companies that willingly finance Chinese investments in technology, biotech, energy, and agri-tech are actively supporting the Chinese Communist Party. These investments will not be limited to the civilian sphere, they will be used by the Chinese defense sector to undermine American interests and global security. Further financing is detrimental international stability - outbound investment to China must cease.

China has proven to be a hostile actor not just in its actions in the South China Sea where it routinely violates international law and seeks to bully its neighbors risking armed conflict. Not even in its constant violation of international trade law, distorting markets and harming industries and employment in countries around the globe. It has a consistent record of violating every norm of behavior and every statute of international law in its wanton belief that it is entitled to hegemony. The theft of technology and intellectual property from the Western world is the most publicized example of China’s brazen disregard for international law. State-sponsored theft, state-sponsored hacking, and corporate espionage under the direction and with the support of the CCP are all part of Chinese statecraft. There can be no illusions that China wishes to peacefully rise and be a part of the global system when it has spent the last few decades stealing its way to the top. American investors must fully divest from China and stop financing their own demise by giving money to the people stealing their IP and technology.

As we evolve our response to the China challenge, there are several areas where we can strengthen offensive and defensive capabilities. The proposed rule offers an opportunity to plug the leaks in our capital markets infrastructure. For too long, investors have gotten away with rewarding their LPs with profits at the cost of American security. That must end and the proposed rule must ensure that there are no carve outs or alternative avenues for hedge funds, endowments, private equity groups, and pension funds that are seeking to finance our enemies and undermine global security and international stability.

Comments.comment:
Public Comment regarding the Environmental Protection Agency Science Advisory Board's review of draft report, "Assessment of the Potential Impacts of Hydraulic Fracturing for Oil and Gas on Drinking Water Resource" (Document Number: 2015-13674)

EPA Science Advisory Board members:

Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) "Assessment of the Potential Impacts of Hydraulic Fracturing for Oil and Gas on Drinking Water Resources " draft report. As scientists and technical specialists, we feel the report is a step forward in understanding the risks of unconventional oil and gas development and that it can begin to offer communities throughout the country the reliable scientific data they seek to make more informed decisions. However, we believe the study can be improved to meet its charge of assessing potential water quality impacts of hydraulic fracturing.

Overall, the report's topline messages in the executive summary and press materials appear not to be congruent with its findings. We ask that the final report be clearer in all communications about the documented cases of water quality impacts found. While it is true that impacts were not found to be widespread across all wells, the report, executive summary, and press materials should clearly and explicitly state the water quality impacts demonstrated by the study's findings in order for citizens and scientists to understand the potential risks associated with hydraulic fracturing.

As technical researchers, we empathize with the data collection limitations that the EPA faced in this research. However, we also encourage more clarity in communicating these research challenges and their impact on the report's findings. For example:
- The study focused narrowly on one part of unconventional oil and gas development, despite evidence of water quality impacts from other steps of the process.
- The study was limited by a lack of baseline testing of water quality conditions prior to the onset of development.
- As the study lightly acknowledges, the work was limited by a lack of access to industry data.

While a substantive amount of research did go into this report, these significant limitations need to be more clearly understandable to the reader. The final report and associated products should acknowledge study limitations up front, emphasize the need for additional study in this area, and contain language that is more measured and consistent with the findings.

Further, we ask that the EPA continue its investigation into water quality impacts of hydraulic fracturing with this study. Clearly, additional assessment is necessary to fully understand the risks to water quality presented by hydraulic fracturing. Most prominently, the agency should develop prospective studies that include comprehensive baseline monitoring. The agency should also use its authority under the Safe Drinking Water Act to investigate alleged cases of water contamination despite anticipated pressures from states and companies against doing so.

Communities deserve access to the best available science on the risks associated with unconventional oil and gas development, and the EPA should play a stronger role in providing that information.

Sincerely,

The undersigned
(475 scientists, researchers, and technical experts)

The era of globalization and the admission of China to the World Trade Organization (WTO) saw the global economy become more interconnected with capital flows between countries skyrocketing. An international environment focused on deepening trade ties with lower tariffs and a global investment environment saw fund managers and capital market actors in the United States chase gains in countries of concern. At the time, China was seen as the adversarial threat it is recognized as today by only a handful of forward-thinking national security officials. Today that recognition is near universal but the actions we take today should have been taken years ago. We are playing catch-up to a country that has been planning our downfall for years.

One of the most compelling reasons to stop outbound investment to China is to protect vital national security interests including the development of cutting edge technologies. Investments in key sectors such as technology, healthcare, defense, and energy all have material impacts on our national security if our adversaries gain a headstart. Financing your enemy is akin to cutting off your nose to spite your face. The difference being, some are actively profiting on undermining America’s security. The government can and should act to stop this.

The Chinese Communist Party’s ever present involvement in the activities of so-called private entities in China means that there is no separation between business and state. They are two heads of the same beast and we cannot continue to pretend otherwise. Companies that willingly finance Chinese investments in technology, biotech, energy, and agri-tech are actively supporting the Chinese Communist Party. These investments will not be limited to the civilian sphere, they will be used by the Chinese defense sector to undermine American interests and global security. Further financing is detrimental international stability - outbound investment to China must cease.

China has proven to be a hostile actor not just in its actions in the South China Sea where it routinely violates international law and seeks to bully its neighbors risking armed conflict. Not even in its constant violation of international trade law, distorting markets and harming industries and employment in countries around the globe. It has a consistent record of violating every norm of behavior and every statute of international law in its wanton belief that it is entitled to hegemony. The theft of technology and intellectual property from the Western world is the most publicized example of China’s brazen disregard for international law. State-sponsored theft, state-sponsored hacking, and corporate espionage under the direction and with the support of the CCP are all part of Chinese statecraft. There can be no illusions that China wishes to peacefully rise and be a part of the global system when it has spent the last few decades stealing its way to the top. American investors must fully divest from China and stop financing their own demise by giving money to the people stealing their IP and technology.

As we evolve our response to the China challenge, there are several areas where we can strengthen offensive and defensive capabilities. The proposed rule offers an opportunity to plug the leaks in our capital markets infrastructure. For too long, investors have gotten away with rewarding their LPs with profits at the cost of American security. That must end and the proposed rule must ensure that there are no carve outs or alternative avenues for hedge funds, endowments, private equity groups, and pension funds that are seeking to finance our enemies and undermine global security and international stability.

attributes.title: - Martin, Leigh

Comments.comment:
I am a physics researcher at UC Berkeley. I am concerned that this rule would severely impact American dominance in science and technology. American educational institutions attract some of the most brilliant people in the world, and it is to our advantage to retain them. According to a 2012 ITIC report, each foreign-born graduate of a U.S. program entering STEM work create[s] on average 2.62 jobs for American workers, from their impact on US innovation and R&D. However, many US physics institutions are suffering potentially destabilizing declines in applications. In some cases, this has forced them to lower their standards for admissions. According to a survey performed by the American Physical Society (APS), these declines are a result of both the perception of the US as unwelcoming to foreigners and the fact that nearly 30% of students trying to come to the US report having challenges obtaining a student visa.

I work in the field of quantum computing, and I can assure you that US dominance in this field is due in no small part to the US's ability to attract brilliant people from all over the world to do research in this field. International students make it to the US through an incredibly competitive system, often winning international competitions to earn their place at our top universities. To discourage them from coming would directly harm our research, and cede this essential edge to our competitors. Just as harmful to US interests would be to force them to leave the US right after we educate them.

H1B applicants already need to show that their wage is competitive. This proposed rule raises the bar to the extent that it is actually higher than salaries at many big tech companies (e.g. Amazon, Google). This change is thus part of a significant effort to discourage talented international students from staying and working in the US, which devastating to the economy and to our research enterprises.

To Whom It May Concern:

Arch Aerial LLC (AALLC) requests to amend Arch Aerial's existing Section 333 Exemption No. 11283, which can be found in Docket FAA-2014-0857, to include exemption from Federal Aviation Regulations ("FARs") detailed in the attachment to this comment for commercial operation of the FPV Model 2.6 Meter Mugin fixed-wing aircraft, in addition to the current standing exemption for the AALLC OCTO.

Attached to this comment is a packet containing the following documents:

Section 333 No. 11283 AALLC Amendment Request
FPV Model 2.6M Mugin Exemption Requests
Arch Aerial LLC Section 333 Exemption No. 11283
Arch Aerial LLC COA FAA-2014-0857
Monthly Maintenance Inspection Checklist
FPV Model 2.6M Mugin Go-For-Flight Pre-Flight Checklist
FAA List of Previously Approved Aircraft

AALLC is submitting this petition for amendment on its own behalf. If the FAA requires any modifications to our amendment request to add approval for commercial UAS operation of the FPV Model 2.6M Mugin, Arch Aerial requests the opportunity to amend this petition for amendment to include any modifications the FAA may require before granting or rejecting the petition for amendment. Arch Aerial will amend its petition to meet any additional standards for the integration of UAS operation into the NAS.

AALLC also requests that this petition for amendment not nullify its current permitted operations using the AALLC OCTO.

AALLC has also recently submitted a petition for amendment to Section 333 Exemption No. 11283 (Document ID: FAA-2014-0857-0028) to include permission to operate the Volantex Ranger in the NAS. AALLC requests that this petition for amendment not nullify approval for AALLC commercial operation of the Volantex Ranger in the NAS.

AALLC has also recently submitted a petition for amendment to Section 333 Exemption No. 11283 to include permission to operate the DJI Inspire 1 in the NAS. AALLC requests that this petition for amendment not nullify approval for AALLC commercial operation of the DJI Inspire 1 in the NAS.

AALLC also requests that the FAA keep materials labeled "CONFIDENTIAL" from the public record for the purpose of maintaining our intellectual property.

Best Regards,
Ryan Lee Baker
CEO, Arch Aerial LLC

Standards of interoperability of networks should become mandatory requirements for networks depending on market cap due to the FREE MARKETS ACT

We will see everything on distributed ledgers and those that are most scalable, ABFT and quantum resistant should lead the way of taking America forward. The Hashgraph algorithm is the most valuable piece of code in cyberspace.

We need to also create easy communication channels between innovators and crypto network by means of standardised frameworks of launching assets on these networks. These need to be standardised in order to deliver mass adoption and not in order to curb any innovation.

attributes.title: Ed Friedman, Maine Coalition to Stop Smart Meters - Comments

Comments.comment:
Every automobile should be doused with the Ebola virus! Offended by this? Then please wake up and get out of the pocket of automobile manufacturers. V2V is nothing more than a deadly industry sponsored effort to increase the spread of what the World Health Organization [WHO] classified a possible carcinogen, radiofrequency [RF] radiation. Cancer risk aside, RF exposure is causing acute medical problems [i.e. heart arythmia, headaches, spontaneous bleeding, rash, exhaustion, etc.] to tens if not hundreds of thousands who may or may not know the cause of their symptoms.

NHTSA asks for scientific information. For Pete's sake spend an hour on the internet looking up terms like smart meter problems, microwave sickness, RF effects. Well documented research on the biological effects of low level [considered non-thermal] RF going back at least 50 years and includes extensive work by DOD, DIA and various branches of the military who saw both health issues from radar exposure and opportunities as non-destructive weaponry. In a world of ever-increasing "electro-smog" we have a coming nightmare the likes of which tobacco and asbestos never saw. Bad enough we have involuntary exposure [esteemed researchers Hallberg & Oberfeld extrapolating from past years of electromagnetic hypersensitivity predict 50% of our population will be sensitive by 2017], to mandate it is nothing less than a crime against humanity and no, I don't in the least consider this hyperbole.

To quote from a colleague in CA:

"I have a Masters Degree in Transportation Planning from the University of the West of England in Bristol, UK, and more than four years experience working to document and reverse the community and individual health damage occurring from wireless technology.

I also have personal experience with electro-sensitivity. In certain situations when exposed to wireless radiation from wireless devices or cell towers, I have experienced headaches, sudden nausea, heart palpitations and other symptoms.

Requiring a device- on every car in the United States- which emits microwave frequencies that can cause these kinds of symptoms in drivers- can in no way be described as a "safety project."

Such a project needs to be put on hold indefinitely, in light of emerging evidence of the carcinogenicity and neurological impairment that can be caused by exposure to wireless radiation, particularly from multiple sources at once, such as with a future scenario from the car's wi-fi, personal cell phone, nearby cell tower, V2V transmitter, nearby smart meters, etc.

The effect of such radiation is cumulative.
Those drivers needing to limit the radiation in their cars- for medical reasons- should be able to do so.
Public transit should have "quiet areas" with no wireless use allowed.

Mandating a toxic "possibly carcinogenic" (according to the World Health Organization) radiation emitter in everyone's car is a violation of the ADA and will be inviting mass non-participation and project failure if it is allowed to proceed without an investigation into the driver safety impacts of exposure to high frequency pulsed microwave radiation.

And speaking personally,

You will have to pry my cold, dead fingers from the steering wheel before I will ever let you install one of these in my car."

We strongly second the quoted comments above and request the V2V proposal be rejected like a gift of Ebola. At the following links some valuable information on health effects of RF can be found. These links don't begin to scratch the surface.

Intervenor filed evidence by category
http://www.mainecoalitiontostopsmartmeters.org/2013/04/intervenor-evidence/

Expert and lay witness testimony in Maine Smart Meter health & safety investigation
http://www.mainecoalitiontostopsmartmeters.org/2013/02/introduction-to-our-puc-filings-of-expert-and-lay-witness-testimony/

One of the most recent comprehensive compendiums on biological effects of RF- Bioinitiatives Report [2012]
http://www.bioinitiative.org/

One of the witnesses in our investigation had this to say and it applies to the illegitimate proliferation of RF emitting devise in general:

Smart meters threaten our health, our privacy, our security and in no small way our human rights, democracy, dignity and way of life. Smart meters are one of the largest uncontrolled toxic biological experiments of our time. An experiment sanctioned by Maine legislators on unsuspecting and trusting citizens, citizens who are getting ill just going home, making dinner, going to bed; living. Their deployment is unconscionable.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Ed Friedman, Spokesperson
Maine Coalition to Stop Smart Meters
Comments.organization: Maine Coalition to Stop Smart Meters

attributes.title: Comment on FR Doc # 2019-12806

Comments.comment:
To the USDA and the Committee for Dietary Guidelines for Americans (DGA),

My name is Dr. Richard M Fleming. I am a Physicist-Physician and I am the author of the "Inflammation and Heart Disease" and "Angina" Theories (Inflammation and Heart Disease; Fleming Unified Theory of Vascular Disease. 1-655833842. Started 9-1-2011. Effective 9-16-2011, TX 7-451-244.). These are the Theories which so many people use to talk about Heart Disease, Cancer and Inflammation.

I have previously provided written testimony at the request of the USDA (01-11-2001), have been a grant reviewer for USDHHS (2006-2016) and served as a Moderator for the Obama-Biden Transition team (12-29-2008).

Most recently, the Editors of The Annals of Internal Medicine included my comments on-line for readers to consider as they reviewed the recent publications on Red Meat and Processed foods and any associated risks for Heart Disease and Cancer.

A decision to alter the current recommendations is NOT well founded. As you will see from my CV (attached), in 2008 I published a paper (attached) showing that measured changes in blood tests (inter alia cholesterol, CRP, fibrinogen) do not correlate with changes in coronary artery disease (CAD) - thus using these blood tests to determine success is not helpful. While it is true these blood tests measure components of the "Inflammation and Heart Disease", they are measure what is present in the blood and not what is present in the tissue (ie. the coronary arteries or tissue where cancer is a concern).

As a further explanation I include the copy of the FMTVDM Study Protocol - in two parts due to the size limitations for submission here - which will allow us to better understand what impact each of the diets actually have. Only by measuring the effect of these diets can an objective series of recommendations be made.

I may be reached for further comments or to answer any questions you might have. I would be available by skype for further discussions or to appear for the committee.

Most respectfully,

Richard M Fleming, PhD, MD, JD

attributes.title: Comment from Richard  Fleming, MD, JD

Comments.comment:
FMTVDM provides the first and only truly quantitative method which can accurately, consistently and reproducibly measure tissue changes allowing differentiation of tissue based upon regional blood flow and metabolism, using any type of nuclear imaging tool. FMTVDM is the only tool which is actually calibrated and the calibration is part of the actual patent itself. As such FMTVDM including the calibration component (TFM) and the cancer component (B.E.S.T. Imaging) allows earlier detection of disease and transitioning states of tissue leading up to the "diseased" state. It is NOT experimental and it is not plagued with the sensitivity and specificity issues associated with qualitative tests. Because FMTVDM-B.E.S.T. can make these measurements, it can also tell you if your treatment is working-or not. This means women and men, receiving the best possible treatment; saving time, money and most importantly - LIVES.

If the FDA is interested in using FMTVDM, we will work with the FDA and HHS to allow for the accurate measurement of which treatments do and do not work, allowing a more rapid investigation of drug and other treatments for both heart disease and cancers. Since it provides "quantitative" measurements, the sample sized and time required to determine treatment effects will be smaller and faster, assisting with the rapid throughput of investigations for drug treatment trials.
